title: 103_s1864
content:
The "Harassment-Free Workplace Act" aims to protect small business employees from sexual harassment, extend sexual harassment laws to private sector employers not covered by current federal laws, and empower the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission to enforce these laws for small businesses. The Act defines key terms such as "commerce," "Commission," "complaining party," and "employee." The term "employee" refers to an individual working for an employer, excluding elected public officials, personal staff of elected officials, and certain appointees. The term "employer" refers to a person engaged in employing individuals. The term "employer" is defined as a person in an industry affecting commerce with fewer than fifteen employees for each working day in 33 or more calendar weeks in the current and preceding year. An "employment agency" is a person who procures employees for an employer. "Industry affecting commerce" includes any activity or business that could hinder commerce. The term "labor organization" refers to a group engaged in an industry affecting commerce, including any agent or employee representation committee dealing with employers on various employment issues. A labor organization is considered to be engaged in an industry affecting commerce if it maintains a hiring hall, procures employees for an employer, or has fewer than 15 members. A labor organization can be certified under the National Labor Relations Act or the Railway Labor Act, be a national or international organization representing employees, have a chartered local organization representing employees, or be chartered by a labor organization. A labor organization can be certified under the National Labor Relations Act or the Railway Labor Act, be a national or international organization representing employees, have a chartered local organization representing employees, or be chartered by a labor organization. The term "person" includes one or more individuals. The term "person" includes individuals, governments, agencies, unions, corporations, and other entities. A "respondent" refers to an employer, employment agency, labor organization, or joint labor-management committee. The term "State" encompasses states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and other territories. The United States includes the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, American Samoa, Guam, Wake Island, the Canal Zone, and Outer Continental Shelf lands. SEC. 4. SEXUAL HARASSMENT. It is unlawful for an employer to engage in sexual harassment as defined by title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. It is also illegal to retaliate against an employee or applicant for opposing such harassment or participating in related proceedings. SEC. 5. ENFORCEMENT, REMEDIES, AND RELATED PROVISIONS. This Act provides powers, remedies, and procedures for enforcement and remedies, including damages, in cases of violations of its provisions. The Act allows for compensatory and punitive damages under specific statutes, in addition to other relief authorized by the Civil Rights Act of 1964. Limitations apply if compensatory damages are awarded for various losses or punitive damages. The Act allows for compensatory and punitive damages under specific statutes, with limitations on the amount of damages that may be awarded based on the number of employees the respondent has. If compensatory or punitive damages are sought, a trial by jury may be demanded. The Act allows for compensatory and punitive damages with limitations based on the number of employees. A trial by jury may be demanded, and the court shall not inform the jury of certain limitations. The Act's application to employers, labor organizations, and committees is similar to Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. State laws are construed in the same manner as specified in Section 708 of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. The Act applies in a similar manner to Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. SEC. 6. POSTING NOTICES.

Every respondent must post a notice approved by the Commission, as prescribed by the Civil Rights Act of 1964, describing the provisions of this Act for employees and job applicants. Violations may result in a fine of up to $100 per offense.

SEC. 7. EFFECTIVE DATE.

The Act will be effective 6 months after enactment.
